fields.headline: In Brief
fields.bodyText: Flood defences Tourists going to Venice face new taxes, as yet unspecified, as the local government attempts to protect the city from the effects of mass tourism. The mayor has been given emergency powers to deal with the damage caused by motorised water traffic which creates wash. The mayor said this week that he intended to begin by levying a tax on tourists and impose strict controls on motorised transport in the city's canals. Venice is still menaced by regular flooding from high tides in the lagoon, with some experts predicting it will sink altogether within a century. The national government has already said it will implement a long-delayed, multibillion-pound mobile flood barrier, despite objections from environmentalists who say that it will damage the ecological balance of the lagoon. There are plans to restrict parts of the Grand Canal to gondolas and rowing boats only. Fewer Gatwick trains Gatwick Express is reducing its early morning and evening service from tomorrow. The trains from London Victoria to Gatwick Airport will run every half hour from 4.30am to 6am when they will run every 15 minutes. In the evening, the service will be half-hourly from 8pm until the last train at 12.30am. For more information, call 08705 301530, gatwickexpress.co.uk. Olympic tickets Sportsworld has been appointed the official ticket and tour operator for the Olympic Games in Athens in 2004 and for the Winter Olympics in Turin two years later. For details and to register interest, call 01235 554844 or email: travel@sportsworld-group.plc.uk. Registration details will be available next year at sportsworld.co.uk. Protection awareness A campaign to promote ATOL (Air Travel Organisers' Licensing) coinciding with the peak summer holiday booking period this month and next, has been launched. The adverts, using the message "ATOL - Don't Go Without", remind holidaymakers to check that their travel company is protected by ATOL before they book air holidays or flights. ATOL is managed by the Civil Aviation Authority and gives comprehensive protection against losing money or being stranded abroad to people in the UK who buy air holidays and flights from tour operators. It is by far the largest travel-protection scheme in the UK, and the only one for flights and air holidays sold by tour operators. Out of Cuba Festival Cruises (020-7734 0005), last week became the first major cruise line in five years to use Cuba as its base. Its ship Mistral has departures on January 11, 18 and 25 for a seven-night Caribbean cruise including visits to Mexico and Gran Cayman. Prices from the UK, including flights via Madrid, start from £745, plus £30 additional security charge. Shropshire on foot A brochure on walking in Shropshire has been produced by Shropshire Tourism, telling you what maps and books you need to take full advantage of the county. For a copy, call 01743 462462, ShropshireBreaks.co.uk.
